title: Outback Steakhouse Owner Cuts Chief Customer Officer Role; Chief marketing officer will assume responsibility for customer strategy
text:
Michael Stutts, the executive vice president who had held the role since May 2019, left Bloomin' Brands on Monday, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. He received a lump sum severance payment of $1.6 million, according to the filing.

Bloomin' Brands has spent the past two years using the customer chief role to build up the company's digital capabilities, a spokeswoman for the company said. This year, the chain introduced a new ordering system and mobile app, and in the quarter ended Sept. 26 saw 70% of its off-premises sales made through digital channels, Chief Executive David Deno told investors last month.

Its overarching customer strategy will now fall under the purview of its senior vice president and chief marketing officer Danielle Vona, who was promoted from Outback Steakhouse's CMO role in June, while Chief Technology Officer Astrid Isaacs, who rejoined the company last month from Subway, will handle the company's customer experience technology.

Augie Ray, vice president of customer experience at Gartner Inc., said it is not uncommon to see chief customer officers employed to look after initiatives designed to produce short-term financial results for a company, such as digital transformation, rather than focusing purely on longer-term customer-centric activities, such as customer research and voice-of-the-customer monitoring.

Almost 90% of 401 customer-experience leaders surveyed in 2019 said their company employs a chief experience officer, chief customer officer or an equivalent, up from 61% in 2017, according to Gartner's most recent Customer Experience Management Survey.

This year alone, Bed Bath & Beyond, Walgreens, McDonald's and Under Armour all appointed their first chief customer or consumer officers.
